Title: Invitation to Tender for Trafford Council's Independent Travel Training Service
Description:
This is an Invitation to Tender for Trafford Council's Independent Travel Training Service. This tender presents providers with an opportunity to support the Children, Families and Wellbeing (CFW) Directorate with the provision of independent travel training to young people and vulnerable adults with Special Educational Needs and disability (SEND). Young people and vulnerable adults with learning disabilities may need extra help or support because of a range of needs, such as understanding, physical or sensory, emotional or behavioural difficulties or difficulties with speech and language. Those who will typically be offered independent travel training will be considered to have 'Moderate Learning Difficulties'. They may or may not receive their education in a Special School.  The aim of an Independent Travel Training Service is to work with young people/vulnerable adults, parents, carers, schools and colleges to develop the ability of young people/vulnerable adults with learning difficulties and/or disabilities to travel independently to school or college.
The service will enable the trainee to plan a journey, work out timetables and learn how to use public transport, helping them to stay safe now and in the future, allowing them to access work and job opportunities as well as increased access to social and leisure activities. A travel trainer may work with more than one trainee during the programme. However, the training should always be delivered on a one-to-one basis to ensure that the young person/adult is receiving the full attention of the trainer and that they are acting independently.

Title: Trafford Council Call-Off on the AGMA Electoral Printing Services
Description:
The 10 Association of Greater Manchester Authorities (AGMA) (Bury, Bolton, Manchester, Oldham, Rochdale, Salford, Stockport, Tameside, Trafford and Wigan), plus associate members Blackpool, Blackburn with Darwen, Warrington and Cheshire East sought to appoint a number of Suppliers to a framework for the collaborative contract for election and registration print services from 8 January 2019 for a maximum four year period (2 years plus a potential extension of a further 2 years if agreed).

This contract will cover print products during the contract period in relation to:- 

a) electoral registration; including the annual electoral registration canvass and specified elements of business as usual year round, rolling registration; and
b) all scheduled and unscheduled elections, in participating local authority areas .

This award notice is for the call-off of Trafford Council to the AGMA Framework.

Title: Sexual and Reproductive Health Services for Stockport, Tameside and Trafford Councils
Description:
Stockport MBC acting on behalf of Stockport, Tameside, and Trafford Councils (The Commissioners) are commissioning an  open access comprehensive integrated sexual and reproductive health service for people of all ages, and also specifically in Stockport and Trafford a dedicated young peopleâ€™s integrated sexual and reproductive health service. The integrated services will meet the sexual and reproductive health needs of residents of the Stockport, Tameside, and Trafford areas through the provision of HIV testing, STI testing and treatment (excluding HIV treatment and care) and contraception and reproductive health services in order to improve sexual health outcomes.

The Commissioners will fund the provider of the service on a block contract basis to offer sexual and reproductive health services for Stockport, Tameside and Trafford residents. The provider must also ensure that comprehensive, open access, sexual and reproductive health services are available to all persons present in their area. 
The service will deliver integrated (not simply co-located) provision provided under one management structure. The provider will work in partnership with other locally commissioned services, both clinical and non-clinical, to maintain and develop homogeneous pathways of care. 
The provider will provide dual trained nursing staff that can provide both contraceptive and STI care to ensure better patient care. "Dual trained" means that clinical nursing staff will have training in both provision of contraception and management of sexually transmitted infections. The provider will also provide medical consultant staff who are dual trained and/sufficient sessions of medical consultant time to enable both STI and contraceptive service provision to be consultant led. 

The Commissioners require the integrated sexual and reproductive health service to operate main hub clinics in each of the three areas. The integrated service will be delivered on a hub and spoke basis with a central point of contact and triage (hub) in the three areas. Routine and intermediate services (Levels 1 and 2) will be delivered from all locations (hub and spoke clinics) and specialist treatment and care (Level 3) will be delivered from the three hub clinics.

The Commissioners require the integrated sexual and reproductive health service in Stockport to continue to host the integrated open access Central Youth Counselling Service for young people in Stockport for ages 11-25. The new provider will be expected to work with the Stockport CAMHS Partnership to ensure provision of an enhanced emotional health and wellbeing offer in Stockport.  

The Commissioners require the integrated sexual and reproductive health service in Stockport to continue to provide a community Gynaecology Service as part of the integrated sexual and reproductive health service. The Community Gynaecology service specification is currently being reviewed and the Provider will be required to work with Stockport

Lot 3 - Innovation Trafford are currently looking for homecare providers who want to play an active role in redesigning the support we offer at home. We are currently trialling different ways of working through targeted prototypes in key areas in Trafford.

Title: CAN (Children with Additional Needs) Short Breaks
Description:
Trafford Council currently has contracts with organisations to deliver short breaks for children with disabilities across Trafford. This includes activities after school and at weekends and a befriending service. Contracts come to an end in August 2017.
We are now looking to commission service to begin delivering on September 1st 2017. To apply for these new opportunities you need first to apply to The Early Help Dynamic Purchasing System. You need to apply under the theme complex and additional needs, one of the six areas covered by the Dynamic Purchasing System (DPS). You can apply for other themes too if you wish. Providers will need to be part of this DPS before being able to bid for short breaks in future competitions. If you have been unsuccessful in the past you are welcome reapply.
Trafford Council's current providers are not based in Trafford, so you do not need to be based in, or currently delivering services in, Trafford. We welcome bids from organisations delivering services in Greater Manchester and in neighbouring authorities.

Title: 3 Extra Care Facilities
Description: Trafford Council are looking to tender the provision of care services for people living in an extra care housing scheme. The purpose of this specification is to protect the service user. In providing services on behalf of the Council, all providers will be expected to maintain high professional standards in carrying out their work. In commissioning these services, the Council will be expected to maintain high professional standards in carrying out their role. Extra care housing schemes entail the provision of rented and/or owner-occupied housing with a range of design features and services that enable vulnerable adults and older people to self-care for longer, promote their independence and facilitate them remaining in their own homes where they might otherwise have to move to a care home environment. The objective of the Council is to enable service users to receive the best possible support services in accordance with the lifestyle and wishes of each individual.

Description:
Trafford Council is committed to providing a high quality, consistent and integrated Advocacy Hub Service. This service will play an important role in maximising people's independence and to promote control by the individual over their care and support and the way in which it is provided.

The primary role of the Hub will be to meet all statutory requirements of the council for the provision of independent advocacy under the terms of the: 
ïƒ˜	Care Act 2014 (ICAA)

ïƒ˜	Mental Health Act 2007 (IMHA)

Title: UID7919 Trafford Healthy Lifestyle Request For Quotation (RFQ)
Description:
Title:

UID7919 Trafford Healthy Lifestyle - Request For Quotation (RFQ)


Description:

Trafford Council and Trafford Housing Trust are looking to support particular groups of people in Trafford to lead healthier lifestyles. We are looking for projects that can help people to amongst other things, stop smoking, be more physically active, eat healthier, feel emotionally strong, and get screened for health conditions earlier. We are only interested in projects that can help people that might find it more difficult to access regular health and wellbeing support. This includes: â€¢ BAME communities â€¢ People with mental health issues from BAME communities â€¢ Deaf community â€¢ People with disabilities and long term health conditions (especially in deprived areas) â€¢ People with learning disabilities and autism â€¢ Older people (especially fuel poverty/ deprived communities). A maximum of Â£195,000 per annum is available for all the projects. This means that if a bidder is only targeting a single group of people from our priorities or impacting a single area of health then his bid should be for less than this amount. We are looking to spread the money available to cover all of the above-mentioned groups. Bidders are able to submit multiple bids for different types of projects but up to a maximum of 3 projects per organisation. Contract Duration: 3 years. Deadline for questions: 12noon on the 20th Nov 2019. - Questions must be uploaded onto The Chest portal. Questions submitted via any other means will not be answered. Deadline for submission of quotations: 12noon on the 27th Nov 2019. Please see the Request For Quotation (RFQ) and other documentation on The Chest portal for details.

Title: Electoral Management System 2015
Description: The contract is for the provision of an electoral registration and elections management system capable of managing all aspects of elections and the electoral registration processes in accordance with current and future legislation and to enable the Returning Officer (RO)/ Electoral Registration Officer (ERO) to meet statutory deadlines. The lead authority for this procurement exercise is Trafford Council on behalf of the Association of Greater Manchester Authorities (AGMA). AGMA is a partnership between 10 Local Authorities and other public sector bodies within the Greater Manchester Area. In addition, AGMA has a number of associate members from Greater Manchester and the surrounding areas. The Local Authority letting the agreement (Trafford Council) will be establishing this agreement by or on behalf of those AGMA members, associate members and the associate bodies linked to these Authorities. The current members of AGMA are: Bolton Council, Bury Council, Manchester City Council, Oldham Metropolitan Borough Council, Rochdale Council, Salford City Council, Stockport Metropolitan Borough Council, Tameside Council, Trafford Council and Wigan Council. The Associate Members of AGMA are: Blackburn with Darwen Council, Blackpool Council, Cheshire East and Warrington Borough Council It is conceivable that AGMA membership and associate membership may change over the life of the AGREEMENT, and hence either expand or contract the list of contracting bodies eligible to use this Agreement. Should any changes occur, then the details of such changes will be made available to interested parties. The contract is let by Trafford Borough Council as a member of AGMA and lead Authority for the collaborative Electoral Management System Framework Agreement. The Framework Agreement is open to all members of AGMA. 10 Councils have fully committed to the solution. They are as follows: Bolton Council Bury Council Manchester City Council Oldham Council Rochdale Council Salford Council Tameside Council Trafford Borough Council Warrington Council Wigan Council  II.1.6) COMMON PROCUREMENT

Title: Supply and Delivery of Beers, Wines, Spirits and Soft Drinks (C109)
Description:
The contract will be for the supply and distribution of an assortment of Beers, Wines, Spirits and Soft Drinks to a number of venues across the Greater Manchester region. 
Tenderers should note that this contract is open to and may be used by other Association of Greater Manchester Authorities (AGMA) and its associate members, and Manchester Partners - this includes the following Councils: Bolton, Stockport,  Tameside, Oldham, Manchester, Rochdale, Bury, Salford, Wigan, Blackburn Darwen BC, Blackpool, Cheshire East, Warrington, and Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Authority, Greater Manchester Police Authority, Greater Manchester Waste Disposal Authority, Manchester Central Convention Complex, Commission for New Economy, Greater Manchester Passenger Transport Executive (TfGM),Transport for Greater Manchester, Greater Manchester Combined Authority and the Integrated Transport Authority, and Lancashire County Council and any of their successor organisations. 
Trafford Council is the lead Council on behalf of AGMA. 
 In the first instance the following Authorities intend to participate in the process: 
 
 Bolton Council 
 Greater Manchester Police 
 Manchester City Council 
 Rochdale Council 
 Salford Council 
 Stockport Council

Title: Best Interest Assessments for Deprivation of Liberty Safeguarding
Description: Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards ( known as DoLS) were introduced, as part of the Mental Capacity Act (2005), to provide a legal framework around the deprivation of liberty. They provide legal protection for vulnerable people who are, or may become, deprived of their liberty when placed or residing in a hospital or care home. DoLS require a 'managing authority' ( ie relevant hospital or care home) to seek authorisation from a 'supervisory body', in this case Trafford Council, to be able to deprive someone lawfully of their liberty. The safeguards apply to people aged 18 or over in England and Wales who have a 'mental disorder' and lack the capacity to consent to care or treatment in a hospital or care home where this may be necessary to prevent them from harm and appears to be in their best interests. The process involves a number of assessments undertaken by a Best Interests Assessor ( a Social Worker with specific training) and a doctor approved under Section 12 of the Mental Health Act 1983 with appropriate DoLS training ( or a registered medical practitioner who meets specified criteria). Trafford council are looking for a provider to complete 200 standard Best Interests and related Assessments (ie Age, Mental Capacity, No Refusals and Selection of Representative) to ensure compliance with legislation and related policy within a 10 week period. To complete up to 100 further Best Interests and related assessments within a further period of time no longer than 6 months from the start of the contract. To provide the opportunity for up to 20 Council Social Work staff trained as BIAs to shadow experienced BIAs, providing practical experience to complement and complete their formal BIA training.
Supplier [Name|Address|Ref type|Ref Numb: [Liquid Personnel Ltd|Sevendale House, Dale Street, Manchester, M1 1JB|NONE||No|No]

Meets one of the following heat source requirements:
o 75% of heat from non-renewable fuelled CHP
o 50% of heat from a renewable source
o 50% recovered heat, or
o 50% of heat from any combination of renewable/ recovered heat and non-renewable fuelled CHP.

Does not result in any customer detriment when compared with the counterfactual/ business as usual case.

Will measurably reduce the input of primary energy required for each unit of energy delivered in a cost effective way, when compared to the baseline/ 'business as usual' scenario.

Has no technical or contractual impediment to future expansion.

Title: Housing Options Service T453
Description:
Housing Needs Service 
The provider will be required to wholeheartedly and willingly take on the responsibilities of the Council and represent the Council in the spirit of true partnership. The provider must take an active part in local joint planning groups with a view to actively promoting the services and effectively engaging with others to improve the services provided. The provider will be expected to take a lead role in developing partnerships and delivering the Council's strategic objectives relating to the services covered by the Housing Needs Services Contract and achieving a Gold Standard Service. 
The Council has a statutory duty to provide housing advice, homelessness and housing waiting list services to the residents of Trafford. The provision of these services is established under the framework of the Housing Act 1996, as amended by the Homelessness Act 2002. 
The nature of the work defined in this specification must take into account the requirements of the Housing Act 1996, the Homelessness Act 2002, the Homelessness (Priority Need for Accommodation) Order 2002, the relevant Codes of Guidance published by Communities and Local Government (CLG), the Localism Act 2011 and any subsequent guidance and targets set by central government. The provider must be able to deliver services given any changes in legislation or in case law. 
Housing Register 
The provider will ensure that a system is in place to allow applicants on the Council's Housing Waiting List to express choice by bidding for available properties. This is outlined in detail in the Council's Allocation Policy.

Title: Working Well Expansion Programme
Description:
The expansion of Working Well is a central pillar of the Greater Manchester Combined Authority's (GMCA) devolution agreement with Central Government.  
  
The ambition of the devolution agreement is to achieve better outcomes for residents by securing significant influence, and ultimately control, over public spending in Greater Manchester (GM). The agreement was made on the condition that the GMCA will adopt a mayoral model of governance. The benefits of the agreement cover a range of thematic areas including investment funds; transport; business support; housing; and planning.  
  
The specific elements of the devolution agreement that are relevant to this tender exercise are:- 
a)    An expanded Working Well programme, ultimately supporting 50,000 people to progress towards employment. Building on the existing programme, Working Well will provide participants with integrated, intensive support.   
b)    A co-commissioned Work Programme. GM will commission, jointly with DWP, Work Programme provision that draws on and complements Working Well expansion, a reformed post 19 skills landscape and broader employment and skills reform.  
c)    A reshaped FE post 19 skills system. GM will incentivise skills providers to focus on meeting the needs of defined GM priority groups, ensuring the right support is in place to move people on to employment or to continue in education.  
d)    A reformed approach to delivering the AGE Grant. Ensuring the use of the grant is aligned with broader support for GM residents and the priority growth sectors across GM.  
e)    Alignment of Skills Capital. Ensuring GM has the infrastructure that supports the delivery of a reformed employment and skills landscape. 
  
In addition to supporting residents into employment, Working Well Expansion will support those in low paid or insecure employment to progress to higher skilled and higher paid jobs. Greater Manchester has low levels of productivity compared with London, and a key outcome of Working Well is to increase productivity levels and reduce dependency of those in work who continue to rely on benefits such as Working Tax Credits.   
  
The Working Well Expansion will consist of three separate elements: personalised support (which this tender pertains to); the Mental Health Therapeutic Interventions tender; and the Skills for Employment tender. It is envisaged that these elements will begin delivery at the same time and they will work together and integrate with other local services, to provide a holistic approach to moving people into sustainable employment. The personalised support is the linchpin of the Working Well Expansion programme and all clients will be supported through this service. 
  
Trafford Metropolitan Borough Council is acting as the procurer on behalf of the GMCA to appoint a provider/s. The programme will be delivered across all ten Local Authority areas of GM: 
Bolton 
Bury 
Manchester 
Oldham 
Rochdale 
Salford 
Stockport 
Ta

Title: Support/Maintenance for the voice platform and core switches
Description:
There are approximately 90 schools and 50 corporate sites, including hybrid locations that support more than one type of customer. In addition, the network also provides connectivity for corporate clients based within non-council establishments including homeworkers (private residencies), health care trust and GM Police concerns.

The infrastructure utilises a number of different suppliers and technologies to interconnect sites; the majority are based on a layer 2 service that is overlaid with a layer 3 OSPF network utilising Alcatel 6200, 6400, 6800 and 6900 series switches for the customer premise equipment.  Each site is evaluated independently to ensure the best solution is chosen to meet the needs of service.

Currently corporate sites support bandwidth levels between 10mbps and 1gbps, primary schools support bandwidth levels between 10mbps and 50mbps and secondary schools currently support bandwidth levels of 100mbps.

An ADSL solution based on an MPLS layer 3 VPN provides connectivity to the network of speeds up to 24mbps for a small number of homeworkers.

The range of services that can be supplied to each of these sites includes internet connectivity, voice, CCTV, Wi-Fi, back up, proxy and security facilities.

Title: GMCA ESF Skills for Growth - SME Skills Support
Description:
Greater Manchester (GM) has secured approx. Â£40m European Social Fund to deliver GM's Skills for Growth Programme. An overview of the full programme has been provided along with the delivery model in the specification in order to set the scene for how the SME Skills Support element of the programme, being procured through this specification, fits in to the wider model.
The programme in its whole is purposefully iterative in its development and commissioning, the aim of which is to put GM in a unique position to build a truly collaborative programme that shapes skills delivery and responds to skills needs that emerge throughout the 3 year programme. 
Skills provision is critical to GM's recovery from Covid19. This programme provides an opportunity to support businesses as they rapidly develop and innovate to maintain and create economic activity and jobs, with a focus on increased productivity through developing the skills of their workforce. The foundational and frontier growth sectors identified in GM's Prosperity Review and Local Industrial Strategy (LIS) will also be key priorities for this programme.

Title: Electoral Management System Call-Off From AGMA Framework
Description:
An electoral management system is required that includes associated support and maintenance. This relates to the legal duty of the Electoral Registration Officer (ERO) and Returning Officer (RO).  The ability of the EMS is to support the delivery of the ERO and RO functions by agreed statutory and non-statutory deadlines are critical factors in the evaluation of the tenders required for all 10 AGMA authorities and Associate Members.  It is crucial to manage all aspects of elections and electoral registration processes. An AGMA framework is currently used by all GM authorities since December 2015. The following Councils are committed to using the framework, Bolton, Bury, Manchester, Oldham, Rochdale, Salford, Tameside, Wigan, Trafford, Blackpool and Blackburn and Darwen.

This award notice is for the Call-Off of Trafford Council.

Title: Temporary Staffing (AGMA)
Description:
AGMA Agency Staffing Contract.

15 members and associate members of the Association of Greater Manchester Authorities (AGMA) will procure agency workers through a collaboratively purchased, 3rd generation hybrid "managed service".

The 15 members of the collaboration are: Blackpool Council, Bolton Council, Bury Council, Greater Manchester Police, Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service, Oldham Council, Rochdale MBC, Salford City Council, Stockport MBC, Stockport Homes, Tameside Council, Transport for Greater Manchester, Trafford Council, Warrington Borough Council and Wigan Council.

The scope of job roles includes all contingent labour roles, directly required by the collaborating Authorities/Organisations that require agency worker engagement.

For the purposes of this tender, the parameters of the term "agency worker" are a temporary worker, engaged by a member of the collaboration from a supplying agency, commanding a pay rate from minimum wage (or living wage) up to Â£35 per hour. These parameters are derived from the AGMA collaboration's own agency population and the terms broadly found in framework guidance.

Title: Weather Forecast Services
Description:
Rochdale Borough Council, acting on behalf of itself and the nine other Greater Manchester Authorities, are seeking to appoint a winter highways weather forecasting service supplier with appropriate skills and resource available to undertake the exacting requirements of the AGMA winter maintenance group (AGMA). 
The Ten Greater Manchester Authorities include:-
Bolton Council
Bury Council
Manchester City Council
Oldham Metropolitan Borough Council
Rochdale Metropolitan Borough Council
Salford City Council
Stockport Metropolitan Borough Council
Tameside Metropolitan Borough Council
Trafford Council
Wigan Council
To maintain the highway network in as safe a condition as possible for its users during adverse weather events has required a combination of technical skills allied to accurate weather forecasts to enable decision makers to plan and implement effective treatments of the highway.  It is therefore very important that weather forecasts can be shown to meet the standards of accuracy and quality for a contract of this type.

Title: Provision to supply and deliver dental supplies (toothbrush and toothpaste dental packs)
Description:
GMCA is seeking a Contractor to supply and deliver dental supplies (toothbrush and toothpaste dental packs),brush busses and individual toothbrush and toothpaste to support the GM dental challenge programmein Oldham, Rochdale, Bolton and Salford. This programmes requires multiple courier delivery drop offs ofthese packs (School, Nursery, Health Centre, Dental Practice and Health Visitor). Additional resources maybe required as part of this programme, particularly in year 2. Other local number of local authorities acrossGreater Manchester commission similar schemes and may wish to order have expressed an interest in orderingadditional resources from the successful bidder. These resources would be in addition to the resourcesand sites specified within this bid. This Oral health programme is delivered by the Greater ManchesterHealth and Social Care partnership in four local authority areas of Greater Manchester, Oldham, Rochdale,Salford and Bolton. This has a fixed cost and remit and forms part of the overall oral health programme forGreater Manchester. The framework agreement will include the option for additional items to be purchasedto deliver other similar programmes on behalf of the Greater Manchester Health and Social Care Partnershipwww.gmhsc.org.uk/ or the 10 local authority areas in Greater Manchester which form AGMA
Bolton Council, Bury Council, Manchester City Council, Oldham Metropolitan Borough Council ,RochdaleCouncil, Salford City Council, Stockport Metropolitan Borough Council, Tameside Council, Trafford Council,Wigan Council and associate members - Blackburn with Darwen Council, Blackpool Council and WarringtonCouncil and Cheshire East Council. It is conceivable that GM and AGMA membership and associatemembership may change over the life of the DPS, and hence either expand or contract the list of purchasingbodies eligible to use this Agreement.
